item.title: Board List Generator Code
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:39, topic:391540”]Could easily use something like xml, but I really don’t feel like making it more complicated than it has to be for something I run every few months and don’t change the keywords for.

And you can easily think about it any way you want, I like to think of enumerations of just a nice way to keep information that is going to be final clean (instead of like creating a new class for it and creating a bunch of final instances of that class in a messier way) I don’t think I’ve read anywhere that enumerations are strictly for symbolizing states, that’s just a common use of them (which I also do)

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/enum.html

Java programming language enum types are much more powerful than their counterparts in other languages. The enum declaration defines a class (called an enum type). The enum class body can include methods and other fields. The compiler automatically adds some special methods when it creates an enum. For example, they have a static values method that returns an array containing all of the values of the enum in the order they are declared. This method is commonly used in combination with the for-each construct to iterate over the values of an enum type. For example, this code from the Planet class example below iterates over all the planets in the solar system.

As you can see, that example doesn’t really store states at all, it’s just a final instance and storage of different information about planets. I do the same thing, except with categories.[/quote]

However, board information used in this manner is an independent variable and therefore is expected to be subject to change. The way you encapsulate the board data is not as dynamic as I believe it should be. Enumerations of this data is really just counter intuitive to helping people create a board list when you must edit the code and not supply it with data that is easy to edit.

Could easily use something like xml, but I really don't feel like making it more complicated than it has to be for something I run every few months and don't change the keywords for.

Fak, it is just lazy programming.

Read full topic

item.title: Board List Generator Code
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Could easily use something like xml, but I really don’t feel like making it more complicated than it has to be for something I run every few months and don’t change the keywords for.

And you can easily think about it any way you want, I like to think of enumerations of just a nice way to keep information that is going to be final clean (instead of like creating a new class for it and creating a bunch of final instances of that class in a messier way) I don’t think I’ve read anywhere that enumerations are strictly for symbolizing states, that’s just a common use of them (which I also do)

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/enum.html

Java programming language enum types are much more powerful than their counterparts in other languages. The enum declaration defines a class (called an enum type). The enum class body can include methods and other fields. The compiler automatically adds some special methods when it creates an enum. For example, they have a static values method that returns an array containing all of the values of the enum in the order they are declared. This method is commonly used in combination with the for-each construct to iterate over the values of an enum type. For example, this code from the Planet class example below iterates over all the planets in the solar system.

As you can see, that example doesn’t really store states at all, it’s just a final instance and storage of different information about planets. I do the same thing, except with categories.

Read full topic

item.title: Board List Generator Code
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:37, topic:391540”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=488704.msg3777597#msg3777597 date=1318203650]
Alright I went through it seriously this time and all I can say is: What was the purpose in doing this and why are you using enumerations excessively?
[/quote]The purpose can be found in the downloads or tutorial sections, and why not?[/quote]

Because the way you are using enumerations does not make logical sense in my mind, why use something that is meant to symbolize a state to encapsulate data that may change depending on the person using it? Java is not a scripting language.

Read full topic
